title: Chatham County Commissioner Shabazz scheduled for court Dec. 7 on traffic violations
text:
Photos Yusuf Shabazz Related Stories Chatham County State Court judges recuse themselves from Commissioner Yusuf Shabazz case Traffic charges against Chatham County Commissioner Yusuf Shabazz waived to state court READ: Chatham County commissioner cited with leaving scene of accident By Jan Skutch Chatham County Commissioner Yusuf Shabazz has been scheduled for a Dec. 9 arraignment before a visiting judge on traffic charges that he allegedly left the scene of an accident with injuries, came back, identified himself, and then left again.
Long County State Court Judge Jeffrey Arnold, who has been assigned to the case after Chatham County’s three State Court judges removed themselves, will hear the first action in the case since Shabazz’s lawyer waived the charges to trial court.
An accusation filed by Assistant District Attorney Andre Pretorius, chief State Court prosecutor, on Oct. 14 charges Shabazz with:
• Reckless driving on June 5 in a Ford Econoline van “by refusing to stop his vehicle after being given verbal and visual commands to do so by Beverly Ferguson, who was directing traffic at the time of the incident.”
• Hit and run by being the driver of a vehicle on Holland Road “which was involved in an accident resulting in an injury to Beverly Ferguson” then failing “to immediately stop at the scene his vehicle at the scene of the accident and return” to the scene.
• Driving on the wrong side of the roadway on Holland Road “fail(ed) to operate said vehicle on the right half of the roadway … under circumstances which were not within any of the exceptions” of the law.
Shabazz’s attorney, Stephanie Burgess, waived the charges to State Court on Sept. 9 during an appearance in Chatham County Recorder’s Court.
Savannah-Chatham police charged Shabazz, 53, with leaving the scene of an accident with injuries, reckless driving and driving on the wrong side of the road, all misdemeanors.
Police said city of Savannah workers were unloading a piece of heavy equipment from the back of a flatbed truck June 5 on Holland Drive and Holland Court when Shabazz drove up in what Savannah-Chatham police said was a non-emergency medical transportation vehicle.
Instead of stopping, the commissioner went around an employee who was serving as a flag person, and a mirror on his vehicle struck the arm she was using to hold the flag, causing minor injuries.
Shabazz apparently kept going, but later returned. He was told police were being called and that he needed to stay, at which point he said, “Tell the police I’m Commissioner Shabazz” and left again, police said.
